channel.description: so what would the answer be to this question? Jenna deposits 500 $ to her bank account. She makes a quarterly interest of 8% for 1 year. How much money would she have by the end of the year? The Formula for this equation would be I=Prt I being the interest (0.08) P being the principle (the money you start with = 500 $) t being the time (1/4 of a year) for one year would equal? :confused:

item.description:

My repetitive method can easy be done with minor programming, so no need to have math skills. Anyways, I will go ahead and drop off right here before this goes too much further.
[/quote]“no need to have math skills” – because programming has NOTHING to do with math. Full reliance on loops is probably the biggest detriment to any program; a difference between 5 seconds for a calculation and 0.00001 seconds.[/quote]
inb4 public boolean process() {

item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Elve, I don’t know where your math is, but 8% of 500 is not 160. Hell, 20% of 500 is 100 alone, so the other 60, would mean 32% of 500. In this pattern, it doesn’t add up because of the interest earned through those quarterly periods.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @the_elve_age the elve age
item.description:
@the_elve_age wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:15, topic:391154”][quote author=Slave Scyth link=topic=487100.msg3570302#msg3570302 date=1302986872]
500(1+(0.08/4))^4

541.22

EDIT: I lied. Read that wrong. Thought it said yearly interest, compounded quarterly. If it’s 0.08 every 1/4 of a year, then it would be:

500(1.08)^4

680.24
[/quote]
You forgot to round up the number, it comes to 680.25 after rounding.

@Elve - Wrong, all of the intrest cannot be done at the same time, as you are not considering the fact, the interest is quarterly, meaning there WILL be money earned every 3 months. This needs to be factored in.[/quote]
Oh…
500*.08=160
760*.08=T2
T2*.08=w/e

At the end total up the totals? I assume, and add 500?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Slave_Scyth Slave Scyth
item.description:
@Slave_Scyth wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:22, topic:391154”]I actually graduated HS with those class’s alone. Got no need for higher class’s though, as I am going for graphics designer, not game development (that is a side-hobby)[/quote]Well, then your math skills aren’t what they should be for any computer-related job; not to mention that most high schools I’ve heard of won’t even allow you to graduate without at least 3 classes. (At least, with an honor’s diploma)

500(1.08)^4 is the equation for this. 4 is the number of quarters. Plug in any number for quarters and it will be dead-on with your repetitive method.

I took algebra1 and geometry1, got something like this in both, that is what my teachers has us do.[/quote]My equation got the answer, did it not? Put it in for 1,000 years; it will be right. You’ll learn about it in higher math classes. (Exponential functions)

item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

import java.math.BigDecimal; public class Paymentcalc { public static void main (String[] args) { double currentMoney = 500.0; double interest; for (int i = 0; i < 4; i++) { interest = (currentMoney * (8.0/100.0)); System.out.println("money is " + currentMoney); System.out.println("-"); System.out.println("interest is: " + interest); System.out.println("-"); currentMoney = currentMoney + interest; System.out.println("payment " + i + " is: "+ currentMoney); System.out.println("-----"); System.out.println(" "); } } }

[code=result]
money is 500.0

interest is: 40.0

payment 0 is: 540.0

money is 540.0

interest is: 43.2

payment 1 is: 583.2

money is 583.2

interest is: 46.656000000000006

payment 2 is: 629.856

money is 629.856

interest is: 50.38848

payment 3 is: 680.24448[/code]
That being said,
/thread

Read full topic

Steps between are needed, unless you have a rather intricate equation that can take the percent, add it, then do this same exact thing over again within itself with the new number. I took algebra1 and geometry1, got something like this in both, that is what my teachers has us do.

EDIT: I lied. Read that wrong. Thought it said yearly interest, compounded quarterly. If it’s 0.08 every 1/4 of a year, then it would be:

500(1.08)^4

680.24
[/quote]
You forgot to round up the number, it comes to 680.25 after rounding.

@Elve - Wrong, all of the intrest cannot be done at the same time, as you are not considering the fact, the interest is quarterly, meaning there WILL be money earned every 3 months. This needs to be factored in.[/quote]I don’t care to round up past the hundredths place.

And for your post above, if you’re getting the actual equation, which I’d assume the teacher is looking for, there shouldn’t be any ‘steps in-between’.
